DIV1.P: ALTER'D from SHIRLEY. As it is Perform'd, BY HIS MAJESTY's SERVANTS▪ AT THE Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane.
LONDON: Printed for J. and R. TONSON, in the Strand. MDCCLVIII. (Price One Shilling.)

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: IN the year 1711, Mr. Charles Johnson alter'd the Gamester, written originally by Shirley, into a Co∣medy, which he call'd the Wife's Relief, or the Husband's Cure: In this play he retain'd Shirley's under-plot of Leonora, Violante and Beaumont; which has no necessary dependance upon the principal action, and had therefore been generally censur'd as impertinent; nor has it, sepa∣rately consider'd, any excellence to attone for that defect. The editor of the Gamesters, as it is now a second time alter'd from Shirley, will not presume to offer any ob∣jections to the alterations and additions which Mr. John∣son has been pleas'd to make—It will be sufficient for him to inform the reader, that he has nothing in common with Johnson, but what both he and Johnson have in common with Shirley. The characters of Barnacle and the Nephew, which were before unconnected with the principal action, are now interwoven with it: what alte∣rations and additions have been now made, will be better known by a comparison of this play with theIt is printed in the 8th volume of the collection of old plays, pub∣lished by Mr. Dodsley. original, and are, with great deference, submitted to the candor of the public.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: WRITTEN AND SPOKEN By Mr. GARRICK.
DIV1.L: WHENE'ER the wits of France take pen in hand,
To give a sketch of you, and this our land;
One settled maxim through the whole you see—
To wit—their great superiority!
Urge what you will, they still have this to say;
That you who ape them, are less wise than they.
'Tis thus these well bred letter-writers use us;
They trip o'er here, with half an eye peruse us;
Embrace us, eat our meat, and then—abuse us.
When this same play was writ, that's now before ye,
The English stage had reach'd its point of glory!
No paulty thefts disgrac'd this author's pen,
He painted English manners, English men;
And form'd his taste on Shakespear and old Ben.
Then were French farces, fashions, quite unknown;
Our wits wrote well, and all they writ their own:
These were the times when no infatuation,
No vicious modes, no zeal for imitation,
Had chang'd, deform'd, and sunk the British nation.
Should you be ever from yourselves estrang'd,
The cock will crow, to see the lion chang'd!
To boast our liberty is weak, and vain,
While tyrant vices in our bosoms reign;
Not liberty alone, a nation saves;
Corrupted freemen are the worst of slaves.
Let Pruia's sons each English breast inflame;
O be our spirit, as our cause, the same!
And as our hearts with one religion glow,
Let us with all their ardors drive the foe,
As heav'n had rais'd our arm, as heav'n had giv'n the blow!
Would you re-kindle all your ancient fires?
Extinguish first your modern, vain desires:
Still it is yours, your glories to retrieve;
Lop but the branches, and the tree shall live:
With these erect a pile for sacrifice!
And in the midst—throw all your cards and dice!
Then fire the heap; and as it sinks to earth,
The British genius shall have second birth!
Shall, Phoenix-like, rise perfect from the flame,
Spring from the dust, and mount again to fame!

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.BYLINE: WRITTEN by a FRIEND, AND SPOKEN by Mrs. CIBBER.
DIV1.L: MY conduct now will every mind employ,
And all my friends, I'm sure, will wish me joy:
'Tis joy indeed, and fairly worth the cost,
To've gain'd the wand'ring heart I once had lost.
Hold, says the prudish dame with scornful sneer,
I must, sweet madam, stop your high career;
Where was your pride, your decency, your sense,
To keep your husband in that strange suspense?
For my part, I abominate these scenes—
No ends compensate for such odious means:
To me, I'm sure—but 'tis not fit to utter—
The very thought has put me in a flutter!
Odious, says miss, of quick and forward parts;
Had she done more, she'd given him his deserts:
O, had the wretch but been a spark of mine,
By Jove, I shou'd have paid him in his coin.
Another critic ventures to declare,
She thinks that cousin Pen has gone too far:
Nay, surely, she has play'd a generous part;
A fair dissembler, with an honest heart.
Wou'd any courtly dame in such a case,
Sollicit, get, and then RESIGN the place?
She knew, good girl, my husbands reformation,
Was (what you'll scarce believe) my only passion:
And when your scheme is good, and smart, and clever,
Cousins have been convenient persons ever.
With all your wisdom, madam, cries a wit,
Had Pen been false, you had been fairly bit:
'Twas dangerous, sure, to tempt her youth with sin;
The knowing-ones are often taken in:
The truly good ne'er treat with indignation,
A natural, unaffected, generous passion;
But with an open, liberal praise, commend
Those means which gain'd the honourable end.
Ye beauteous, happy fair, who know to bless,
Warm'd by a mutual flame, this truth confess;
That should we every various pleasure prove,
There's nothing like the heart of him we love.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I.

SP.SPEAKER: WILDING.
SP.L: WHAT need you be so coy now?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Pray collect
Yorself; remember what you are, and whose:
You have a virtuous gentlewoman; think
Upon your faith to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Think of a fiddle-stick!
While you put me in mind of what I am,
You quite forget yourself. My wife I allow
Your kinswoman far off; to whom, a widow,
Your father left you, with a handsome fortune;
Which, by her marriage, I have in possession,
And you too: therefore, as you hope to be
In due time worth a husband, think upon't.
I can deserve respect; then wisely use me,
As you would keep me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: This is but a trial
Of my strength; for I know you have more charity,
(Should I consent) than shipwreck your own honour.
But take heed, sir, how you proceed to jest
With frailty; left too much disordering
Your good thoughts, you forget, and by degrees
Lose your own innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I jest? you'd have me swear:
And yet you should not think it such a wonder
To love, sure. Come, shake off this frost; it spoils thee;
Your nature should be soft and flexible.
Perhaps, thou think'st—I do not love thee heartily:
I know not how to give thee better testimony,
Than by offering myself to thee: if my wife die,
(As ten to one she's not immortal) we
May couple t'other way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: What argument is this
To assure the truth of your affection to me,
That break your vows to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Oh! great argument,
An you observe: she was a widow, when
I marry'd her; thou'rt a young maid, and hand∣some.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Can you be so ungrateful then, to punish
Whom you should reward? Remember, sir, she brought you
That wealth you have; took you from nothing—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: There's reason then for nothing I should love her.
Hang her estate! I was held a proper man;
And in that point deserv'd her, an' she had millions:
An' I were free again, I would not draw
I'th'team of marriage, for ten subsidies;
Not to command a province.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Yet you said,
Were your wife dead, you'd marry me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Only thee, and no body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: 'Twere dangerous to have many.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: To have one, is little less than madness come, wo't promise?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: A'course you know my meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wil.
SP.L: I do not like this whispering; why with her
So close in parly?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Wo't thou do this feat for me?
'Tis finish'd in a pair of minutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Yes, upon one condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: What condition?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: That your wife give consent; you shall then command me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I'll undertake to go a pilgrimage
To Jerusalem, and return sooner. Wou'd
I did not love thee, love thee infinitely—
That's all; 'tw'nnot do—My wife!—I hope
She has not eaves-dropp'd us. What pity 'tis
She cannot find the way to heav'n? I should not
Trouble her in haste. These wives will have no con∣science,
But stick to us everlastingly! Now, lady,
How did your monkey rest last night? you look
As you had not said your prayers yet; I won't dis∣turb you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Pray, sir, stay; let me but know
Some reason, why you use me thus unkindly?
If I have been guilty of offence, I am not
Past hope, but with the knowledge of my error
'Tis possible I may amend and please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I do not like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: You did marry me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Yes, I did marry you; here's too much re∣cord for't.
I would there were a parson to unmarry us!
If any of our clergy had that faculty,
He might repair the old, and build as many
New abbeys through the kingdom, in a twelve-month.
Shall I speak truth? I never much affected thee:
I married thee for thy soul's sake, not thy body:
Yet I do not hate thee. Witness, I dare kiss;
Hold thee by the hand, sleep in the same house,
Nay, in the same bed sometimes; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: What, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: You have a scurvy quality, wife; I told you on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Once more; and I'll correct it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: You are given to be jealous. I cannot
Ramble abroad in gentlemen's company
Whole days, lie out a nights, but you suspect
I am wanton. 'Tis ill done; it becomes no modest
Woman that loves her husband, to be jealous,
Whate'er she sees or hears; mend, mend this fault,
You do not know how it may work upon me.
Some wives will bid their husband's leverets welcome;
Nay, keep house together; but you ne'er did it:
Know their own chamber, and not come forth
'Till they be sent for. These morals I have read
Before now, but you put them not in practice;
Nor, for ought I perceive, have disposition to't:
Therefore I'll take my course.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: To shew I can
Be obedient to my griefs; from this time, sir,
I wo'not urge with one unwelcome syllable,
How much I am neglected; I'll conceal it
Too from the world: your shame must needs be mine.
I see you do not love me; where your heart
Hath plac'd a worthier thought, let it dwell ever;
Freely pursue your pleasures; I will have
No passion that shall mutiny; you are,
And shall be lord of me still.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I like this, if it be no disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Do not suspect me;
I would swear by a kiss, if you'd vouchsafe it;
You shall not keep a servant, that shall be more humble.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: And obedient to my will?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: In all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I'll try you then.

DIV2.L: But if I bring home a mistress—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I'll be patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: What if there be one
Already, that does please me? will you not
Repine, and look awry upon's, when we
Make much of one another?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: So you will but sometimes smile on me too, I'll endeavour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Well said, this may do good upon me; as
I find you prompt in this, I may consider
Other matters: to tell you true, I like
Your kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: How? why as a man shou'd like her; but
I find her cold and peevish. How she may
Be brought about, I know not. 'Twould shew well,
And be a precedent for other wives,
If you would put your help to't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Goodness bless me!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: One woman with another can do more,
In such a cause, than twenty men. I do not
Wander, you see, out of the blood; this will
Be a way to justify your obedience.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: You shew a tyrant now; and, stead of framing
My soul to patience, murder both.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Nay, nay, child, if you are out of humour at trifles, I must leave you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Stay, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Not now, my dear—when you are cool again, you may expect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: This is not to be borne; my patience is worn out; and, one way or other, I must have some respite to my tortures.

SP.SPEAKER: Wilding, solus.
SP.P:
I have gone too far, a conscience—this may spoil all; and, now I think upon't, I was a cox∣comb to discover any party.—I must deny't again, and carry things more closely—But let me see, why
do I use this wife of mine thus terribly?—she gave me all—ay, that all's the devil! my desires are sa∣tisfied, and I have not a grain of inclination left;—variety is the thing—in eating, music, wine, or women; nothing but variety gives the palate to them all: now, my wife is always the same tune, the same dish, the same dull bottle of port; and, to sum up all, the same woman—'twill never do— How now, Will?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: How now, Will? is that all?
Look up, and ask me a question like a man;
What, melancholy?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No, no; a toy, a trifle.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: That should be a woman; who is't thou art thinking on?
I have been of your counsel—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I was thinking—o'my wife!
We have had a dialogue; come, thou know'st my bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: When do'st mean to use her well?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I know not; but I have offer'd fair conditions.
She is very confident I do not doat
Upon her beauty: I have told her, sirrah,
I love her kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Y'are not so mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The world's deceiv'd in her; she'll give me leave
To ramble where I list; and feed upon
What best delights my appetite.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: He that has
An ambition to be strangled in his sleep,
May tell his wife he loves another woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: But I was not content with this. Because
The other wench was somewhat obstinate,
I must needs urge my wife to mollify
And mold her for my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And she consented?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No, 'twould not do:
This went against her stomach, and we parted.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Next time you see her, look to be presented
With your mistress' nose for this. Do'st think a woman
Can be so patient, to know her rival
I'th' same roof, and leave her eyes to see thee
Again? I am sorry for thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I am confident
She dare not: but for all that, would I had
Been less particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Come, I love thee well;
But not thy wit, to carry things no handsomer:
You must unravel again, and make your wife
Believe you did but try her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Prithee drop the subject; don't set my teeth on edge with talking so much about, my wife.—Can'st not see by my wry faces, that 'tis holding the vial to my nose, after I have taken the physic.—Prithee no more of her—now tell me, what brought thee this way!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I was going to meet old Barnacle.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild. Barnacle!
SP.P: what can such opposites possibly do together? He wants you to beat some body for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Faith, Jack, I have no superfluous valour to dispose of—I have but just enough to defend my∣self from the impertinence of some, and the villainy of others.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: A gamester by profession, Will, shou'd be always ready to draw his sword, as the circumstances of play, and the support of his honour may re∣quire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Yes, there are gamesters who are ever draw∣ing their swords to support their honour, and of consequence are for ever fighting.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P:
And they find their account in't—For gen∣tlemen in general had much rather submit to have
their pockets pickt, than run the risque of having their throats cut: but prithee, Hazard, how do you escape these firedrakes; for you are pretty open and direct in your censures upon 'em?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: What will they get by quarrelling with me? they know I dare fight, and that I hate a scoundrel; and whenever madam Fortune is pleas'd to jilt, and strip me, I always fall upon her bullies; and as they don't love fighting, for fighting sake, they call me an odd fellow, and let me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! but to return to Barnacle— What is become of that genius his nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Just now return'd from college, as great a genius as he went—He has been exposing himself these two years at the university, in the cha∣racters of the rake and the scholar, and now is come up to make the same figure in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Is not he an insufferable blockhead?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Yes, an insufferable blockhead; but not ab∣solutely ignorant—his tutor has got words into him without ideas; so his folly and scholarship set one another off to a most ridiculous advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: What Greek and Latin he has, I suppose lies in his head, as his uncle's money does in the chest, without being of the least use to himself, or any body else.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: You are mistaken, sir; his uncle will spare no expence to make his hopeful kinsman a fine gen∣tleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild▪
SP.P: Then the matter is out—he comes to bind him apprentice to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Your humble servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: His debauchery will become him as little as his learning; so that in time we shall see the hopeful youth not only contemptible but infamous.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Is not that the old gentleman yonder, com∣ing this way?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P:
It is indeed; and therefore I shall leave you to your entertainment—squeeze a few hundreds out
of him if you can—I must back to my kinswoman— I can't rest without her—Shall I see you at the old place this afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: You shall—I wish I cou'd get this Penelope out of his hands. She's a charming girl, and tho' she has not quite money enough to be made a wife of, by one of no fortune, yet she has too many good qualities to be made a strumpet of, by such a fellow as Wilding—he will not succeed surely— what should be the business, that old Barnacle has desired my conference? 'tis not to lend me money sure—he's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Master Hazard!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I was coming to you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
Haz.
SP.L: Mine? command it, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Nay, I'll be thankful too; [Shewing a purse of money.] I know you are
À gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: That should incline you to think
I am not mercenary.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I beseech your, sir,
Mistake me not; rewards are due to virtues,
And honour must be cherish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What's your purpose?
Pray clear my understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: To be plain, sir,
You have a name i'th' town for a brave fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: How, sir! you do not come to jeer me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Patience, I mean you have the opinion
Of a valiant gentleman; one that dares
Fight and maintain your honour against odds.
The sword-men do acknowledge you; the bailiffs
Observe their distance; all the swaggering puffs
Strike their top-sails. I have heard them in the streets
Say—there goes daring Hazard; a man careless
Of wounds; and tho' he has not had the luck
To kill so many as another, dares
Fight with all them that have.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You have heard this?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: And more, and more; mistake not,
I do not all this while account you in
The list of those are called the blades, that roar
In brothels, and break windows, that swear dammees,
To pay their debts; and march like walking armories,
With poniard, pistol, rapier, and batoon,
As they would murder all the king's liege people,
And blow down streets: no, I repute you valiant
Indeed, and honour'd; and come now, without
More ceremony, to desire your favour;
Which as you are a gentleman, I hope,
You'll not deny me.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Though your language
Be something strange, yet because I think you dare not
Intend me an abuse, I not question it.
Pray to the point; I do not think you're come
To have me be your second.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I am no fighter;
Tho' I have seen a fence-school in my days,
And crack'd a cudgel; yet I come about
A fighting business.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You would have me beat somebody for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Not so, noble Hazard: yet
I come to entreat a valiant courtesy,
Which I am willing to requite in money;
I have brought gold to give you payment, sir;
'Tis a thing you may easily consent to,
And 'twill oblige me ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Be particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Then thus; you are not ignorant I have a nephew, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You have so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: One that's like
To be my heir; the only one of my name
That's left: and one that may in time be made
A pretty fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Very well; proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You know, or you imagine, that I have
A pretty estate too.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Y'are held a main rich man, sir;
In money able to weigh down an alderman.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I have more than I shall spend: now I come close;
I would have this nephew of mine converse with gen∣tlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And he does so.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I'll not pinch him in's allowance;
The university had almost spoil'd him.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: With what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: With modesty; a thing, you know,
Not here in fashion: but that's almost cur'd;
I would allow him to be drunk—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You may, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Or any thing, to speak him a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: With your favour, sir, let me be bold a little
To interrupt you; were not you a citizen?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: 'Tis confess'd, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: It being a thriving way,
A walk wherein you might direct your nephew,
Why d'ye not breed him so?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I apprehend;
And thus I satisfy you: we that had
Our breeding from a trade, cits as you call us,
Tho' we hate gentlemen ourselves, yet are
Ambitious to make all our children gentlemen:
In three generations they return again;
We for our children purchase land; they brave it
I'th' country, beget children, and they sell;
Grow poor, and send their sons up to be 'prentices:
There is a whirl in fate. The courtiers make
Us cuckolds; mark, we wriggle into their
Estates; poverty makes their children citizens,
Our sons cuckold them. A circular justice!
The world turns round. But once more to the pur∣pose.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: To your nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: This nephew of mine I do love dearly;
He is all my care; I would be loath to lose him;
And to preserve him both in life and honour,
I come to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Now you come to me, indeed, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What shall I give you, sir, to let him—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pray, be not angry!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: By no means.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: There is no such security i'th' world;
I'll pay for't heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: For what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: What shall I give you, troth, and let him—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Beat you, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Nay do not, sir, mistake me: for altho'
I name it coarsely, I desire it should be
With your consent, no otherwise: my nephew
Is raw, and wants opinion; and the talk
Of such a thing! to beat a gentleman
That all the town's afraid of, would be worth,
In's credit, heaven knows what! alas, you cannot
Blame a kind uncle, to desire all means
To get his nephew fame, and keep him safe;
And this were such a way!—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: To have me beaten.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Y' are i'th' right; but do not misconceive me.
Under your favour, my intention is not
He should much hurt you: if you please to let him
Quarrel, or so, at tavern, or where else
You shall think fit; and throw a pottle-pot—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: At my head?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Yes; or a bottle; still under your correction;
Only that some of your acquaintance, and
Gentlemen may take notice, that he dares
Affront you, and come off with honor handsomely.
Look, here's a hundred pieces! tell 'em i'th' ordinary;
Th'are weight, upon my credit: play 'em not
Against light gold: This is the prologue to
My thanks; besides my nephew shall in private
Acknowledge himself beholden.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: A hundred pieces! I want money.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You give me this to let your nephew beat me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Pray, take me with ye: I do not mean he should
By beating, hurt you dangerously—You may
Contrive the quarrel, so that he may draw
Some blood; or knock you o'er the pate, and so forth;
And come off bravely; this is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Well, sir;
You do not mean, you say, he should endanger
My life or limbs; all you desire, if I
Mistake not, is to get your nephew credit;
That being flesh'd, he may walk securely, and be held
Valiant, by gaining honour upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You understand me right.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I'll put it up;
Pray send your nephew to me; we'll agree.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Agree, sir? you must quarrel, and he must beat you;
Else, 'tis no bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Not before
We have concluded how things shall be carry'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I must desire your secrefy, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Here's my hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: And there's my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Your nephew shall be a blade.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Why there's ten pieces more, 'cause you come off
So freely; I'll send him to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Do so; why this, if the dice favour me, may bring all
My lands again. Be sure you send him; but
No words! for your nephew's credit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Mum—I thank you heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Be there such things i'th' world? I'll first to the tavern;
There I am staid for: gentlemen, I come;
I'll be beat every day for such a sum.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Wilding and the Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: WHERE's you master, boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: I know not, mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Come nearer, sirrah; you are of your master's
Council sometimes; come, be true in what
I shall desire, and I shall find a time for your reward.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: How d'ye mean, mistress?
We pages meet rewards of several natures:
This great man gives us gold; that lady, gloves;
T'other, silk slockings, roses, garters: but
The lady and mistress whom we serve in ordinary,
Reserves another bounty for our closeness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I see you can be a wag; but be just to me, and secret—

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: As your looking-glass;
That in your absence cannot be corrupted
To betray your complexion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: What private mistresses does master Wilding visit?

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: Who, my master?
Alas, forsooth, d'ye think he lets me know?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Nay, nay, dissemble not.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: I hire a coach
Sometimes, or so, but ride always i'th' boot;
I look at nobody but the passengers.
I do not sit i'th' same box at plays with them;
I wait at tavern, I confess, and so forth;
And when he has sup'd, we must have time to eat too:
And what should I trouble my conscience
With being too officious till I am call'd for?
'Tis true, he waits upon the ladies home;
But 'tis so dark, I know not where they dwell:
And the next day we have new ones; 'las, meer strangers
To me, and I should be unmannerly
To catechize 'em. If now and then there be
Any superfluous cast waiting-woman,
There be so many serving-men about her,
I cannot come to ask a question;
And how should I know any thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I see you are old enough for vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: Alas, forsooth,
You know 'tis ill to do a thing that's wicked,
But 'twere a double sin to talk on't too,
If I were guilty; beside forsooth, I know
You would ne'er trust me again, if I should tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Thou art deceiv'd, it shall endear thee more.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: I must beseech you
To be excus'd; my master is my master;
My feet are at your service, not my tongue:
I would not forfeit my honour for the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Hence, thou old in villainy!
But 'tis in vain to chide: leave me, and bid
Mistress Penelope come hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: Yes, forsooth.—She is so frumpish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I know not which way to begin: to me
He has betray'd he loves her. Here she is;
Now to the tryal.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Will you be sad still, cousin? Why d'ye grieve?
Be kinder to yourself. Trust me, I weep,
When I am alone, for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Sorrow and I
Are taking leave, I hope; and these are only
Some drops after the cloud has wept its violence.
Were one thing finish'd, I should ne'er be sad more;
And I cannot despair to know it done,
Since the effect depends upon your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: My love! 'tis justice you command my service: I would I were so happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Make me so,
By your consent to my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Pray name it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I only ask your love; pray give it me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: My love! why do you mock my poor heart, which
Pours all it has upon you? y'are possess'd of that already.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: You examine not
The extent of my request; for when you have
Given what I ask, your love; you must no more
Direct it as you please: the power's in me
How to dispose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: And you shall for ever;
I have no passion that shall not know obedience to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Your love, by gift
Made mine, I give my husband. Do you love him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I always did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: But in a nearer way:
Love him as I do?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I understand you not; or if you do
Suspect I cherish any lawless flame—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Thou art too innocent: be less, and do
An act to endear us both: I know he loves thee;
Meet it, dear cuz; 'tis all I beg of thee;
I know you think it a most strange request,
But it will make me fortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Grief, I fear,
Hath made her wild.—D'ye know what you desire?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Yes, that you love my husband: modesty
Will not allow me to discourse my wish
In every circumstance; but think how desperate
My wound is, that would have so strange a cure.
He'll love me then; and, trust me, I'll not study
Revenge, as other wives perhaps would do,
But thank thee; and indeed an act like this,
So full of love, with so much loss and shame too
For mine and his sake, will deserve all duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I have no patience to hear more; and could
I let in a thought you meant this earnest,
I should forget I knew you; but you cannot
Be fall'n from so much goodness. I confess
I have no confidence in your husband's virtue;
He has attempted me; but shall hope sooner
To leave a stain upon the sun, than bribe
Me to so foul a guilt. I have no life
Without my innocence; and you cannot make
Yourself more miserable than to wish it from me.
Oh, do not lose the merit of your faith
And truth to him, tho' he forget himself,
By thinking to relieve yourself thus sinfully:
But sure you do but try me all this while.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: And I have found thee pure: be still pre∣serv'd so.
But he will straggle farther—

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Cherish hope;
He rather will come back: your tears and prayers
Cannot be lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I charge thee by thy love,
Yet be rul'd by me. I'll not be so wicked
To tempt thee in a thought shall blemish thee;
But as thou would'st desire my peace, and his
Conversion, if his wantonness last with him,
Appear more tractable; allow him so much
Favour, in smile and language, that he may not
Think it impossible to prevail at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: This may engage him farther, and myself to a dishonour.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: It shall work our happiness,
As I will manage things; 'tis but to seem:
A look will cost thee nothing, nor a smile,
To make his hopes more pleasing: on my life
Thou shalt be safe both in thy fame and person.
Will you do this for my sake?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I'll refuse no danger, if I suffer not in honor,
To do you any service.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I have cast it
Already in my brain; but do not yet
Inquire my purpose: as his folly leads
Him to pursue you, let me know; and I'll
By fair degrees acquaint you with my plot;
Which built on no foul ends, is like to prosper;
And see, how aptly he presents himself—
Pr'ythee seem kind, and leave the rest to me.
He shall not see me,

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: How now, cuz, was that
My wife went off?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Let her go: what said she to thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Thou art troubled!

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Pray, to your knowledge, sir, wherein have I
Done injury to you, or her?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Has she abus'd thee?
I'll go kick her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: By no means, fir—I steal away your heart,
And meet at stol'n embraces?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Does she twit thee? I'll kick her like a foot-ball, Say but the word.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: By no means think upon't: I have forgiven her.
You sha'not, sir, so much as frown upon her;
Pray do not, as you love me; we must study
A more convenient revenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: How is this?
I pr'ythee, if she has been peremptory,
Which was none of our articles, let me instruct thee
How we shall be reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Sir, I acknowledge
The growth and expectation of my fortune
Is in your love; and tho' I would not wrong her—
And yet, to have my innocence accus'd,
Is able to pervert it. Sir, your pardon;
I have been passionate: pray love your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No, no, I'll love thee; indeed, indeed, I will.
Is she jealous?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: You know she has no cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Let us be wise, and give her cause: shall's cuz?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Sir, if I be a trouble to your house,
Your breath shall soon discharge me: I had thought
The tie of blood might have gain'd some respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Discharge thee the house? I'll discharge her,
And all her generation, thee excepted;
And thou shalt do't thyself; by this, thou shalt:
Ha, she kisses with more freedom! this is better
Than if my wife had pleaded for me. Pen,
Thou shalt be mistress, wil't thou? come, thou shalt:
She's fit for drudgery.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Oh, do not say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Then I wo'not; but I love thee for thy spirit,
Cause thou wilt be reveng'd. Punish her jealousy
The right way: when 'tis done, I would chuse
To tell her: it may kick up her heels another way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Tell her what? you make me blush.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No, no, I'll tell nobody, by this hand, I will not. [Kisses it] Stay, stay, I have a diamond will be∣come this finger—'tis in my drawer above, I'll fetch it strait.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: O, by no means.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: 'Tis thine, 'tis thine, my girl—my soul is thine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Indeed, Mrs. Wilding, this is going a little too far for you—there is something so like reality in all I have been doing, that I am more than half in a fever with it already—this playing with fire is a very foolish thing, but tho' I burn my singers I must go thro' with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Here it is, Pen, as sparkling as thyself; wear it, and let my Wife stare out her eyes upon't.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I wo'not take't on such conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Take it on any, take it one any—
She's come about.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.P: Sir, Master Hazard desires your company at the tavern—he says there are none but gentlemen of your acquaintance, Mr. Careless, Mr. Littlestock, and Mr. Sellaway.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: He must excuse me—get you gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Stay, stay, boy—As you love me go, sir—Your master will come. [Exit Page.]—Have no suspicions that I wish your absence; I'll wear your gift, and study to be grateful.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: I'll leave my boy behind—and shou'd my wife be set on gossiping this afternoon, pretend thou, girl, some slight indisposition to keep at home; and when she's gone, let me but know it, and I'll leave the happiest run of dice to catch a moment with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I want not such strong proofs of your regard;
I will not stop your fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Then I'll not leave you now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: You must; indeed you must—When I can oblige you. I shall not prove ungrateful.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Both wind and tide are for me!—No talk now of wife's consent, I'll not remove my siege—When I can oblige you!—Oh, 'twas sweetly spoken!—She is my own! I have her sure! quite sure—Now to the tavern and drink to the purpose.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, The tavern.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hazard, Acreless, Littlestock, Sellaway, and Drawer.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: More wine.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Right, noble Hazard, here's to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Let it come, boy; fill it me steeple high, I am in the vein of mirth, and I ha' cause, as you shall see in due time, gentlemen. Mr. Littlestock, thou art dream∣ing o'th' dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: He's melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: Who, I?

SP.SPEAKER: Hz.
SP.P: I'll play the farrier then, and drench thee for the sullens. A health to all our mistresses; we have had 'em single, let's shuffle 'em now together. [Drinks.] Come, let us join a little music to our wine, and if his me∣lancholy stands 'em both, I'll lay all the money in my pocket, which is no small sum, that he has a two-penny cord about him, and will make use of it before to-morrow morning.—Come, Tom, give us the gamester's apology, and if these are only qualms of conscience, this song will warm him like a dram.

DIV4.HEAD: SONG.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: To eat and to dress all your aim;
To make friends of the dice
All the world plays the best of the game.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Will dupe all they can without shame:
In our turn be as free,
All the world plays the best of the game.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: For the law plays the best of the game.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: To talk of his darts and his flame:
Who is left with the worst of the game.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: To foolish fond man does the same:
When the fool's in the net,
And her spouse has the worst of the game.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: And mount to the summit of fame!
And at court play the best of the game.

LG.HEAD: VII.
LG.L: And swear the proud foe they will tame;
When they think of their bones,
And for them play the best of the game.

LG.HEAD: VIII.
LG.L: Pray think not my notions to blame;
All the world plays the best of the game.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: 'Tis joyous faith—I wonder Jack Wilding stays.—He's come in the nick.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Save, save you, gallants; may a man come i'th' rear.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Give him his garnish.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Y'are not prisoners for the reckoning, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: For the reck'ning! Now y'are all together, gen∣tlemen, I'll shew you a wonder—but come not too near; keep out o'th' circle—whatsoever you think on't, this is a hundred pound! Nay not so close; these pictures do shew best at distance, gentlemen—You see it—Presto.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Nay, let's see it again.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Like to your cunning juggler, I ne'er shew my trick but once; you may hear more hereafter; what think you of this, Mr. Acreless, Mr. Littlestock, and Mr. Sellaway?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: We do not believe 'tis gold.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Perish then in your infidelity.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Let me but touch it.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: It will endure, take my Word for it—look you, for your satisfactions—no gloves off—you have devices to defalk—preserve your talons, and your talents, 'till you meet with more convenient gamesters.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: How cam'st by it?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Thou'dst little or none this morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I have bought it, gentlemen; and you in a mist,
Shall see what I paid for it. Thou hast not drank yet, Wilding,
Ne'er fear the reck'ning, man:—More wine, you varlets!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: But, hark thee, hark thee, Will, did'st win it?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: No; but I may lose it e'er I go to bed;
Do'st think't shall musty? what's a hundred pound?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: A miracle! but they are ceas'd with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: And me too. Come, let's drink.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No matter how it came, Will: I congratulate
Thy fortune, and will quit thee now with good
News of myself. My cuz, I told thee of;
Is wheel'd about: she has took a ring of me;—
We kiss'd, and talk'd, time out o'mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I know it;
My almanack says 'tis a good day to woo in;
Confirm'd by Erra Pater, that honest Jew too.
I'll pledge thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Mr. Hazard, there are two gentlemen below enquire for you; and, Mr. Wilding, this note for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wil.
SP.L: For me?—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What kind of men are they?

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.L: One's somewhat ancient; I heard him call The other nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Victoria! Victoria! Will, a summons from the island of love—my wife's absent, and Pen and I shall toy away an hour, without fear or molestation.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
Wild.
SP.P: What, a moralizing gamester! ha, ha, ha, 'tis envy, Will, attacks thee in the shape of conscience: and was I like the foolish dog in the fable, to catch at the shadow, and drop my tit bit, thou wouldst be the first to snap it up— but I have not time to laugh at thee—I must away— the wench calls, and I must fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: This affair perplexes me—How little do we know of women! had I had fortune enough to have ven∣tur'd upon marriage, I would have fixt upon this cousin of his, preferable to the whole sex—but the devil is in them, and will peep out one time or other—I don't know why, but I am vex'd at this affair—I'll never go to Wilding's house again.

SP.SPEAKER: Draw.
SP.P: Mr. Hazard, the gentlemen without are impa∣tient to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I beg their pardon, I had forgot 'em. I do cau∣tion you, gentlemen, beforehand to be fair condition'd; one of them, the nephew, is of a fiery constitution, and sen∣sible of any affront: let this character prepare him for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Bring him not hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: There is a necessity in it; I would not for a hun∣dred pound but entertain him, now he knows I am here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: Why must we keep company with his disagreeable acquaintance?

DIV4.STAGE: Enter Hazard again; with Barnacle, his Nephew, and Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: This is old Barnacle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lit.
SP.L: And that's his nephew; I have been in his com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: Is this the youth Hazard prepar'd us for?
How busy they are!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You could not wish better opportunity:
These are all gentlemen of quality.
I'll call him cousin first, if it please you,
To endear him to their acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
Neph.
SP.L: But d'ye hear, uncle, are you sure you have made
Your bargain wisely? they may cut my throat
When you are gone; and what are you the wiser?
Dwindle, be you close to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I warrant you, we shall do things with discre∣tion;
If he has but grace to look and talk courageously.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: He may be valiant for aught I know;
Howsoever this will be a secure way
To have him thought so, if he beat you soundly.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: I do not like the company;
But I have drank wine too, and that's the best on't;
We may quarrel on even terms. Look to't Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.L: Here's your safeguard.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: As I am a gentleman—be confident—
I'll wait on you down, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: By no means; let him beat you to purpose, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Depend upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: And when he has beat you, sir, I must beg ano∣ther favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: O, command me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Courage, you know, not only keeps the men in awe, but makes the women admire.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What, must I pimp for your nephew too?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Lack-a-day! no, no, no; tho I'll let him have his swing too—but I must marry him forthwith; and I have one in my eye, that will fit him to a tittle.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Who is the happy creature you have destin'd for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: No less a jewel, I assure you, than your friend's ward, Penelope; there's money and beauty enough! will you put in a word for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Both to the lady, and my friend, and immedi∣ately too.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Only to clear the way a little, Mr. Hazard; I have a tongue myself, and can use it too, when once it is set a going.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I have heard of you at the hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Nay, and my nephew can speech it too: ay, and has your rappartees too, when he's a little in drink, and he shan't want for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: You're in the right, master Barnacle, not to let the hinges rust for want of a little oyling.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I have another purse for you, if you'll introduce us.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I'll do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: But don't forget to be beaten tho'.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Do you suspect my honor?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I don't, I don't—Well, nephew, mind your hits—Mr. Hazard, yours—I am full of joy!—and nephew, draw blood, do you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Bye, nuncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Come, sir; pray, gentlemen, bid my kinsman welcome; a spark that will demand your friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: His kinsman!—You are welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: He has power to command your welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.P: If I mistake not, I have had the happiness to a' been in your company before now.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Mine, sir?—d'ye hear, what if I quarrel'd

DIV4.L: With him first? 'twill prepare me the better.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Do as you please; that's without my conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: I'll but give him now and then a touch; I'll close
Well enough, I warrant you,—You been in my Company, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: Yes, and at the tavern.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: I paid the reck'ning then.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: You came into our room—

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Tell me of coming into your room!
I'll come again. You are a superfluous gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Let him alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: Sir, remember yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: I'll remember what I please, and forget what
I remember. Tell me of a reck'ning! what is't?
I'll pay't: no man shall make an ass of me,
Farther than I list. I care not a fiddle-stick
For any man's thund'ring: he that affronts
Me, is the son of a worm, and his father a whore.
I care not a straw, nor a broken point
For you. If any man dare drink to me,
I wo'nt go behind the door to pledge him.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Why here's to you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Why there's to you, sir. Twit me with coming into a room! I could find in my heart to throw a pottle-pot,—I name nobody—I will kick any man down stairs, that cannot behave himself like a gentleman. None but a slave would offer to pay a reck'ning before me. Where's the drawer? there's a piece at all adventures. He that is my friend, I care not a rush; if any man be my enemy, he is an idle compa∣nion, and I honor him with all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: This is a precious humour. Is he used to these mistakes?

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: Your kinsman gives you privilege.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I desire no man's privilege: it skills not whe∣ther I be kin to any man living.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Nay, nay, cousin, pray let me persuade you.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: You persuade me! for what acquaintance? mind your business, and speak with your taylor.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: An' you be thus rude—

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Rude, sir! what then, sir?—hold me, Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: Nay, nay, Will, we bear with him for your sake:
He is your kinsman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I am calm again:
Cousin, I am sorry any person here
Hath given you offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Perhaps, sir, you
Have given me offence. I do not fear you.
I have knock'd as round a fellow in my days.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And may again—

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: Be knock'd! A pox upon him: I know not what to make of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Let me speak a word in private, sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I can be as private as you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Strike me a box o'th' ear presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: There's my hand on't—

SP.SPEAKER: Sall.
SP.P: Nay, nay, gentlemen—

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.P: Mr. Hazard—

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Let him call me to account: the reck'ning's paid.
Come, Dwindle—Veni, vidi, vici. Huzza!

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: The fellow's mad: does he often mistake thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: His courage is a little hard mouth'd, it runs away with him now and then; we must exchange a thrust or two; after bleeding he'll be cool.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: The youth has a mind to shew himself; he is just launch'd into life.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.P: He'll be soon launch'd out of it agen, if he goes on in this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Prithee let's have no more of him; I shall un∣dertake to cure his fever—But, harkee, friends, shall we meet at the old place this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: By all means, there will be deep play, I hear— my water mark is but low; but I'll go as deep as I can. Will not Wilding be of our party too?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: No, no; he has a love-matter upon his hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: A love-matter! let him but hear the rattling of the dice, and it will bring him from the arms of the finest woman in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Pooh, pooh! you carry this too far.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: I know him in this particular better than you Ha∣zard—when he is in the circle of the gaming-table, 'tis all magic, he has not power to move; and I challenge the devil to bait his hook with a stronger temptation to draw him out of it—besides, among ourselves, what was once with him occasional pleasure, is now become a ne∣cessary occupation: Jack Wilding has made a large gap in the widow's jointure.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P:
Pshaw! rot your gossiping, don't abuse the ge∣nerous
wine you have been drinking, by mixing such scandal as this with it—stay till you get with your mi∣stresses over their rataia, and when you're maulding open the sluices of slander;—However we'll try the experi∣ment; I'll meet you in the evening, and we'll write to him from the field of battle, and see to which his cou∣rage most inlines:
SP.L: From love to gaming we'll his heart entice,
But woman will prevail,—

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: —I say the dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: THIS humour does become thee; I knew when
Thou didst consider what was offer'd thee,
Thy fullenness would shake off. Now thou look'st.
Fresher than morning; in thy melancholy,
Thy clothes became thee not.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Y'are i'th' right;
I blam'd my taylor for't; but I find now,
The fault was in my countenance. Wou'd we had
Some musick; I could dance now; la,la,la,

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Excellent! what a time shall I have on't?
Zounds, I am all on fire: how she glides!
Thou wot not fail, Pen?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: This night—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: At the hour of twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: But you must be as punctual i'th conditions,
For my vow's sake; not speak a syllable.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I'll rather cut my tongue out than offend thee;
Kissing is no language.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: If it be not too loud;
We must not be seen together, to avoid
Suspicion; I would not for a world my cousin
Should know on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: She shall die in ignorance.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: No light I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The devil shall not see us
With his sawcer eyes: and if he stumble in
The dark, there sha'not be a stone i'th' chamber
To strike out fire with's horns. All things shall be
So close, no lightning shall peep in upon us.
Oh, how I long for midnight!

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I have a scruple.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Oh, by no means, no scruples now.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: When you
Have your desires upon me, you will soon
Grow cold in your affection, and neglect me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Why, hang me if I do, I'll love thee ever;
I have cast already, to preserve thy honour;
Thou shalt be married in a fortnight, cuz;
Let me alone to find thee out a husband,
Handsome and fit enough; we will love then too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: When I am married?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Without fear, or wit;
Cum privilegio, when thou hast a husband;
Dost think I will forsake thee, Pen? 'twere pity
O my life, sweet—I shall love thee the better;
And I must tell thee—
'Tis my ambition to make a cuckold;
The only pleasure o'th' world: that imagination
Sweetens the rest, and I do love it mainly, mainly.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: 'Tis double sin.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: 'Tis treble pleasure, wench;
But we lose time, and may endanger thus
My wife into a jealousy, if she see us.
Farewel, farewel, dear Pen; at night remember;
I wo'not lose my sport for half an empire!

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: O my fears, your wife's return'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The devil she is! what shall we do, Pen?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: I'll retire—but seem you more kind to her, lest her suspicions shou'd betray us.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: I will do any thing—I have a holiday in my heart—away, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: What, Mr. Wilding so soon return'd—with smiles upon your face too—this is unusual; what has happen'd, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Why saith, wife, I have been reflecting on my con∣duct towards thee, and could I but hope you would forget my past behaviour, your life to come should be all sunshine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Is not this change too sudden to be certain? what has caus'd it, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Conscience, conscience, my dear—tho' vanity and pleasure lull'd it for a time, it has now awak'd with all its stings, and shewn me all thy virtues, and my errors.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Pray heav'n that I am awake, for this is so like a dream.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Don't you be an infidel, wife, and reject the good now that is offer'd you. I tell you I'm another man; I am converted—when did you see me before with such pleasure in my face?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Not this many a day—Has our cousin Penelope, husband, help'd forward this conversion?—If she has, I am greatly oblig'd to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: You are, indeed, wife, much oblig'd to her; she has done all in her power I can assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Was not she here with you, at my com∣ing in?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Yes, yes, she was here—she was indeed—was here with me—I have open'd my mind to her—and with much zeal and friendship to you, she has confirm'd me in my new faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: How much I am bound to her!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Your are, indeed, wife:—You have not better friend in the world, I can tell you that—Now, what do you want?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Some gentlemen are waiting for you at the old place, and desire your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: You may tell them, that your master has forsaken his old haunts, he has seen the folly of 'em, and retires—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Hold, hold, wife—such a message as this will make us the talk of the town; I will steal myself gently from my friends and pleasures, and rather wean, than tear myself from them—Let them know I will attend them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: As you please—Farewel, my penitent.—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Farewel, my prudence—Had not this mes∣sage come luckily to my assistance, my hypocrisy had been out of breath, and the devil had peep'd out, in spite of all the pains I had taken to conceal it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: How have I enjoy'd his confusion! faith, cou∣sin, you acted it bravely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I am sorry that I am forc'd to dissemble.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: The best of us can, and must, upon proper occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Thou hast hit my instructions excellently.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: I have made work for somebody—you have put me upon a desperate service; if you do not relieve me, I am finely serv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: All has succeeded to my wish: thy place I will supply to-night; if he observe all the conditions, I may deceive my husband into kindness, and we both live to reward thee better—O, dear cuz, take heed, by my example, upon whom thou placest thy affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear, you take this too deeply; my life for it, but we shall reclaim him at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: That I almost despair of; and not so much from his total disregard of me, and his pursuit of other women, as from his uncontroulable passion for gaming.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: He has understanding with all his frailties; and when those violent, irregular inclinations have had their scope, they must return to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: The passion of gaming, my dear, is not to be conquer'd even by the best understandings; it is an absolute whirlpool; wit, sense, love, friendship, and every virtue, are merely leaves and straws, that float upon the surface of the tide; which, as they ap∣proach this gulf, are all drawn in, and sink to the bot∣tom, as if they had never been.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Master Hazard—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Save you, Mrs. Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: You are welcome, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: He is a handsome gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Gone abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: This moment left us, and as I thought to meet you, and his other sober friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I call'd upon him to attend him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: The servant shall overtake him, and bring him back to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: 'Tis too much trouble.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: What! for the best friend of the best of husbands! you wrong me, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Thou art the best of women, I am sure—Ha! this is the very gentlewoman!—in good time—Now for my promise to old Barnacle—I'll accost her—What a pity 'tis, this wench should be a morsel for that glut∣ton Wilding?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: What a pity 'tis, this fellow should be a game∣ster, and companion of my modest guardian?—How he eyes me?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Your name is Penelope, I take it, Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: If you take it, I hope you will give it me again.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What again?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: My name.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Would not you change it, if you cou'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: For the better, surely.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Wilt thou dispose of thyself?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Can you tell me of any honest man, whom I may trust myself with?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I'll tell thee a hundred.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Take heed what you say, sir,—a hundred honest men! why, if there were so many in the city, 'twere enough to forfeit their charter—but, perhaps, you live in the suburbs.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: This wench will jeer me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I hope you are not one, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: One of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: One of those honest men you talk'd of so, to whom a maiden might intrust herself?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: You have hit me, lady; come, I'll give thee counsel; and more, I'll help thee to a chapman too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Alas! no chapmen now-a-days. Gentlemen are such strange creatures, so infinitely cold, and so void of every passion, that a handsome woman cannot reach your pity—Why have you this so strange antipathy to us? To what end will gentlemen come, if this frost holds?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: You are witty; but I suppose you have no cause of such complaint—though some men may want warmth, there is no general winter; and if I guess aright, you'll never be frost-nipt, lady—at least you may prevent it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Are you acquainted with any knight errants, who would succour a distrest damsel?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Yes, I know of one—ay, and a bold one too, that dares adventure with you; nay, will take you for better and for worse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: And is he young too?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: O, very young.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: And wise?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Not over wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Yourself, belike.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Indeed, not over-wise, I must confess; nor yet so witless, lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P:
Who is the hero? is he of your school? is it from you that he has learnt to travel the fashionable
road—Can he drink, dice, roar, rake and royster? scour the streets a-nights, draw forth his valour, which the bottle gives him, upon the feeble watch; but should danger come—what would your hero then? ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Hold, hold; you'll never get a husband, lady, if thus you let your tongue out-run your wit.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Is he to get then? I thought that he was ready caught, and you had brought him in a cage.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Will you accept him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: What in a poke? unseen, untry'd? has the youth no name?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Ay, and a weighty one—'tis Barnacle; young, rich and handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Was this at his intreaty, or your own kind charity?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Lookee, lady, lose not time in questions— husbands are not so plenty—will you have him?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: I thank you for your goodness, sir,—and would advise you, if you have more of these commodities, to take 'em to another market—I am supply'd already— and so your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Gad-a-mercy! thou art a girl of spirit;—sup∣ply'd already? What can she mean?—not Wilding sure!—impossible!—There is something about her, that bespeaks her honest—I know not what to make of her—she may be a tumbler for all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My master, sir, will be at the appointment as soon as possible—he must call at his banker's first, and then he'll attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: 'Tis well;—this Penelope has touch'd me strangely—she is certainly—but what's that to me?—I'll go, and drown thought at the gaming∣table.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, a room in a tavern.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: Was my message deliver'd to Wilding?

SP.SPEAKER: Box.
SP.L: Yes, sir—he will certainly attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: What gamesters have you within?

SP.SPEAKER: Box.
SP.L: The old set, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: What, no strangers?

SP.SPEAKER: Box.
SP.L: A country gentleman or two.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: Will they make sport, think'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Box.
SP.P: The rooks are about 'em: if they are full of feathers (as I believe they are) we shall have rare picking.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.P: Well, do you set them a-going, and I will be among 'em presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I could not come sooner, but don't you lose time—I must write a note, and will be with you at the table presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Hazard alone.
SP.P: What is the meaning, I can't tell, but it hurts me to think that this foolish girl should so easily hearken to the lewd call of this fellow Wilding—this abandon'd, unfeeling fellow! perhaps 'tis his vanity—I did not perceive, 'till she was in danger, that the agreeable jade had given me any concern—What is the reason, that to be eminently vicious is the readiest road to a woman's heart; nay, even to the best of 'em?—but I'll rattle this nonsense out of my head; I have a hundred in my pocket, and the dice are set a dancing—I'll strike up among 'em, and drown reflection—What, Wilding!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Yes, you rogue, 'tis Wilding; the happy, gay, rapturous Wilding! wish me joy, joy, man!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What, is your wife dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: No, but my mistress is kind, which is very near as good a thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Thou art not mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No, no; but I swell with imagination,
Like a tall ship bound for the fortunate islands;
Top, and top-gallant, my flags, and my figaries
Upon me, with a lusty gale of wind,
Able to rend my sails; I shall o'errun
And sink thy little bark of understanding,
In my career; I fly before the wind, boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Pray heaven rather
You do not spring a leak, and forfeit your
Ballast, my confident man of war; I
Have known as stout a ship been cast away
In sight o'th' harbour.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The wench, the wench, boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: The vessel you have been chasing—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Has struck sail;
Is come in; and cries, aboard my new lord of
The Mediterranean. We are agreed:
This is the precious night, Will, twelve the hour,
That I must take possession of all, all,
You rogue you!—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Prithee descend from thy raptures, for the game∣sters are now coming, and we lose time.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The house fills a-pace; what are these, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
Wild
SP.P: And may, if he pleases, when I have made her fit for him—If I have the first glass, he shall take the rest of the bottle, and welcome—But are you in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Prithee talk to him, and hear his overtures— He may be worth your list'ning to—I'll to the table—if I win, I shall have no cause to repent my bargain with him; if I lose, by these hilts, I'll make him the cause, and beat him—Prithee keep him from me a few minutes, and then I'll relieve thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: But how shall I do it?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Tell him any whimsical tale; he is so absurd, that it will go glibly down.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I'll try his swallow then.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Then luck with a hundred pieces!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: I must get a fool for her, and if this will bite, he is ready got to my hands.

DIV3.STAGE: [Takes a news-paper out of his pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Dwindle, that gentleman there is the guardian to the lady that I am to be in love with—Shou'd not I shew away to him, and astonish him with a little learn∣ing, eh, Dwindle?

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: Do, sir,—let off a little Greek at him, and I warrant he'll be proud to call you cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
Dwin.
SP.L: Ask him, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Quem librum legis, domine?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Have you any commands with me, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: If you have any news, sir, pray impart—I have a great appetite for news—vouchsafe me a slice.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: A meal if you please—be there no more gentle∣men to hear? 'tis extraordinary fine news, in black and white, from terra incognita.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Terra incognita! What has it no name?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: If it has, it is asham'd of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: But what are they doing there?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Nothing at all—'tis inhabited by a nation with∣out heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Without heads! where are their eyes then?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: They lost them first, sir, then their heads; and they say the distemper, if not stopt, will spread over the rest of their body.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: O wonderful! a gentleman would not chuse to travel there—Harkee, Dwindle, this is very curious.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.L: Too curious to be true.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: He's upon his fun, Dwindle; I'll humour him—But pray, sir, how can they know one another without their heads?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: They don't; they are so chang'd, sir, they are neither known by themselves or other people; having no heads, sir, they are continually playing at Blindman's buff, for the diversion of their neighbours.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Monstrum! orrendum! informe! ingens! cui lumen ademptum—ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Ha! ha! extremely good; apt and witty.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.L: Now's your time—to him, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I should be proud, sir, to have some nearer con∣nections with a gentleman of your learning, and profound erudition.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: I should be happy to know how, sir, and proud to be your friend and servant, in the true sense of the words.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Dwindle, my affairs are in a fine way—in every sense, I am your humble servant in secula seculorum. You must know, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: I'll know it by and by, if you please—we are interrupted; let us sport away a few pounds at the table, and then I'll go to the tavern, and be at your service in secula seculorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Come along, Dwindle; if my fortune goes on as swimmingly as she has begun, I shall make a rare night on't.—If I get my mistress, and fill my pockets, we'll be as drunk as lords—Come along, Dwindle.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE draws, and discovers the gaming-table—game∣sters at play; after some time, and calling different mains,

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: A curse upon those reeling dice! that last in, and in;
Was out of way ten pieces. Can'st lend me any
Money? How have the dice dealt with thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Aere.
SP.L: Lost, lost—I defy thee. If my luck recover not,
I must be sober to-morrow—damn'd, damn'd fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: Oh, for a hundred, and all made now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: Yonder's Hazard wins tyrannically, without Mercy, he came in but with a hundred pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: I'll get a fancy presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Acre.
SP.L: And how thrive the bones with his lordship?

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.P: His lordship's bones are not well set; they are maliciously bent against him; they will run him quite out of all.

DIV3.P: Boxkeeper calls again several mains; and after some warm play, and much money is won and lost,

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: More money! Dwindle, call my uncle! I must have it, for my honor: two hundred pieces more will serve my turn: in the mean time, I will play away my coat, and some superfluous things about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: By that time you are come to your shirt, I shall be with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: He's blown up too.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: So, so, the dice in two or three such nights will be out of my debt; and I may live to be a landlord again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: You are fortune's minion, Hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You wou'd seem to be no fool, because she doats not
Upon you. Gentlemen, I must take my chance; 'twas
A lucky hundred pound! Jack Wilding,

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Chewing the cud a little; I have lost all my mo∣ney, Will;
Thou hast made a fortunate night on't: wo't play
No more?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: 'Tis the first time I had the grace
To give off a winner—I wou'd not tempt the dice.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: What hast won?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You do not hear me complain;
I have not been so warm these ten weeks.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: 'Tis frost in my pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: Acre.
SP.P: Master Hazard, I was afraid you had been gone; there's a fresh gamester come in, with his pockets full of gold: he dazzles the gamesters, and no man has stock to play with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The devil! what is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Acre.
SP.L: A merchant he seems; he may be worth your return.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Not for the exchange to-night, I am resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Temptation! now have I an infinite itch to this merchant's pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Thou wo't venture again then?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: I wou'd if I cou'd—but what do I forget? the wench, the fairy at home expects me.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I had forgot too: you wo'not play now?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: 'Tis now upon the time. [Looking at his watch. Curs'd misfortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You will not stay then.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Hum—I ha' lost my money, and may recover a pretty wench. Which hand? this wantonness; this co∣vetousness; money is the heavier. Will, dost hear? I'll requite thy courtesy—lend me two hundred pounds to attack the merchant, and I will give thee good interest, and the best security.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What, the dice! and your old luck, Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: No, damn the dice—I will give it thee upon Pen's fortune; she is so loving that I can command her, and her's.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: No matter for her fortune, I'll be contented with less; pay me with the girl herself.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: How do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I'll be contented with her personal security.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Prithee be plain; I am in haste, and every rat∣tle of the dice makes my heart beat to be at the merchant—What wou'd'st have? I'll agree to any thing, every thing—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: The wench at home expects you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Well—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Let me supply thy place.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And here are the two hundred pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: What! no—no—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Nay, then your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Stay, Will—now, now the devil is at work with me—he has thrown out two baits, and I know not which to strike at.—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I must take my money home—yours—Jack, yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Stay, stay, thou shalt, Will—I love thee for thy generosity—Gold is a real good, woman an imaginary one—Besides, a losing gamester will make but a cool lover; thou art warm'd with success, and de∣serv'st her—She will be mine another time—Thou shalt have her.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Shall I?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Done.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: And done.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: There are bills for your money.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: To-morrow you'll thank me for't—Be secret, she'll never know thee, for our conditions are to [whis∣pers him.] neither light, nor—and she must needs con∣ceive 'tis I—Here's my key—It conducts you up the back way into the house—The servants are in bed, the first door on the right hand in the gallery leads to her apartment.—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Are you in earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Have you wit to apprehend the courtesie?
Let me alone; the wench and I shall meet
Hereafter, and be merry: take my key—
The merchant's money cools: away; be wise,
And keep conditions: I must to the gamester;
Farewel; remember not to speak a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What kiss and tell; O, fie for shame—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Success to thee, Will—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And to thee, Jack.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Wilding and Penelope, with candles.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I wish it may answer your purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: I cannot lose any thing by the tryal, the scheme is an innocent one; and if I can but rouse my husband a little from his lethargy, to the least sense of shame, who knows what may happen?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Hark!—are you sure you heard nothing?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Nothing but your maid, going to bed—

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Not come yet—It is past the time too—'Tis very strange!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear Pen, this lover of yours is most terribly unpolite.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: My vanity is a little mortified at it, I must con∣fess—A fine gallant, indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: You see child, this gaming! it destroys every other passion, good or bad—And what hopes think you have I to draw him from the spell, when even you, Penelope, with all your charms, cannot break the en∣chantment?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Who knows but there may be some better way to account for his stay; why may not his conscience, and his reason together, have debated this matter a little seri∣ously? and tho' they have been tollerably pliant hereto∣fore, may grow resty at a crime of this nature.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Come, come, let us not flatter ourselves too far; his reason, and conscience are at present very good friends with his passions, and attend him with great alacrity in all his parties of pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Hark! I am sure I hear him—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed you are mistaken, 'tis your pride now that fancies so—Don't imagine that he'll cast a single thought upon you, while he has a single guinea in his pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Ay, ay, that's your jealousy, cousin—But I know—Upon my word I hear him—Indeed I do— hark!—he's now unlocking the door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: No, no, hush—You are in the right—I hear my thief—he's coming the back way—take the candles into your chamber, and be ready to come in at the signal—Bless me, how frighted I am!

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Are you, my dear? then do you take my part, and I'll take yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Get you gone you fool; I am not in a condition to trifle—I have more at stake than you ima∣gine. [Exit Penelope, with candles.] Now for it; I wish it was over.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P:
I thought I never should have got hither—but where I am, I can neither feel or tell—And now I am
here, I cou'd almost wish myself back again.—I have some qualms about this business—and were I not afraid of being laugh'd at, I would certainly return—But thanks to the spirit of the times, gentlemen are much less afraid of being profligate than ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: He has certainly been drinking—by his muttering so to himself—Now to catch my spark— Hem, hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: There she is, and all my fears are fled—Hem, hem.

DIV3.STAGE: [They approach, and when they meet, he offers to kiss her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: How violent he is! I have not had such a favour from him these two years.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: How modest we are!

DIV3.L: What's the matter! ha! a light—
Who have we got here? we are discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Discover'd! ha! [Screams.]—Who are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: What's the matter here?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Mrs. Wilding!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Mr. Hazard!

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Your servant, good folks! (curtseying) what my good cousin and Mr Hazard at hide and seek in the gallery, in my guardian's absence—you are a most ge∣nerous gentleman indeed! you are for providing every way, I see, for distrest ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: For heav'ns sake, Mr. Hazard, how got you here?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Upon my soul, madam, I scarce can tell you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: You have squeez'd my fingers most un∣mercifully.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: So! so!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Upon my soul, madam, it was all a mistake.
My errand at present was not with you, but with that lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: With me! what business pray, to pinch my fingers?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Here are my credentials—(shews a key) I was only to act by deputation, from a certain friend of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Which I suppose is a certain good guardian of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: And who is most certainly my virtuous husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I am so astonish'd, I hardly know whether I am awake.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: To be sure!—you unlock peoples doors, get into their houses, seize upon their wives, and all in your sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Ladies, tho' I may, perhaps, suffer in your opi∣nions by my silence—yet I could wish, for my friend's sake, my own, and yours, that you would give me your pardon, and peaceably send me about my business; for indeed I am most sincerely asham'd and sorry.
