SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Poor, modest gentleman!—Had a housebreaker been caught in the fact, he would have made just the same apology—but no pardon from me, without a free and full confession.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: I can say nothing, Mr. Hazard, in your justification; but if you have a mind to make all the amends in your power, you will join with me in a plot I have just now thought of; for tho' Mr. Wilding may not have love enough to be jealous of me, I know he has too much pride to be easy, if he thought I was false to him; and what must he feel when he believes me inno∣cently so, and knows himself to be the cause of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: I adore you, my dear Mrs. Wilding, for the thought; I long to be reveng'd on him for his base de∣sign upon me, and now you have him in your power— if you don't torment him thoroughly, I'll never forgive you as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Let me alone for that—Mr. Hazard has only to behave, as if he had succeeded in his design upon you, but let us confer notes together below stairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Ladies, you shall command my life, and my best services.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Best, and worst, they are always ready—I'll say that for Mr. Hazard—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Indeed, lady, you know but half of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: The worst half—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I fear so; but let me assure you both, that with all my frailties, I am much happier in forwarding this scheme of virtue, than I should have been in the success of my folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: I am confident of it—don't mind her, Mr. Hazard, but follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: The Devil was sick, the Devil a monk would be;
The Devil was well, the devil a monk was he.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, Wilding's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: BUT has not master Hazard, in no wise, open'd his business to you, lady, your husband, or your fair coufin? I had his promise for it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: What business, good sir; I pray you speak—This interruption is unfortunate.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Thus then; I have, lady, a longing as it were, to be more nearly connected with your family.—You must needs know what I wou'd say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Indeed I am no scholar, and this is all Greek to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: 'Tis the peculiar blessing of the times; our young men are so learned and brave, and our old ones so wise and virtuous, that we are the astonishment of the whole world! 'tis the golden age, sir!—But your bu∣siness.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Vouchsafe me, lady, one plain answer to an ho∣nest question—Has your fair kinswoman, the beauteous Penelope, yet transferr'd her affections to any one happy mortal?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: If she had not, wou'd mr. Barnacle be∣come a purchaser?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Me, madam! no, no, no! alas, alas, my danc∣ing days are over—But for my nephew—Oh, that ne∣phew of mine! You have seen him, and heard of him surely—Have you not, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: My mind of late, Mr. Barnacle, has had little attention, but to its own troubles.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Alack, alack! I know it well—You are much discours'd of and pitied by the world; and I'll be bold to say, if there be any man that troubles you, or any that you would have talk'd withal, let him be who he will— I'll rid you of that care—He that shall offer to disturb you but in a thought, do you mark me, madam? I'll take an order with him—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: What will you do, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Don't mistake me, I'll do nothing—But I'll send my nephew—He shall work him, and jerk him, I war∣rant you—You don't know how my nephew is improv'd fince he came from the university; he is a perfect knight errant, the very St. George for England!—Why, madam, he has had a pluck at the very flower of chivalry, ay, and cropt it too—the very Donzel del Phebo of the time, and all the roaring blades lower their top -gsails to him— I'll say no more—Name but the man, whom you but frown upon, and I'll send my nephew to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: I thank you, sir, I have no enemy to ex∣ercise his prowess upon, my discontents are known to flow from a nearer person—I am asham'd to say—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar
SP.P: Your husband—Say but the word, and I'll send my nephew to him; and he were ten husbands he should mollify him—Don't spare him—Had you but seen him baffle a squire this morning!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: These praises of your nephew, mr. Barna∣cle, are thrown away upon me; 'tis my cousin must be warm'd with 'em—And here she comes; so I shall leave your eloquence to present the flower of chivalry to her, which I think would be an ornament to the fairest bosom in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Madam, you do my nephew honor, and when you are in the humour to have any man beaten, either in your own family, or in the kingdom—I'll send my ne∣phew to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Dear Pen, dispatch this old fool as fast as you can, and in the mean time, I'll dispatch my page, to fetch my wand ring turtle home.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Fair lady, I am your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Good Sir, I am yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I fear my visit may offend.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: I am but ill at ease, indeed, sir, and most unfit for company.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: What, so young, and melancholy—O, 'tis a pity.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: It is, indeed, and yet I am melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And for what, fair lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: For a gentleman—What wou'd you have a fair lady melancholy for?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: I'll send my nephew to him—

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: To bring him to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Ay, bring him, and swing him, if you desire it—You can make him do any thing, madam—Say you but the word and he'll take the great Turk by the whiskers—O my nephew is a pretty fellow! don't you know him, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Not I, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Not know my nephew!—I'll send him to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: What to do, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: He shall do any thing—the town's afraid of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: O, pray keep him from me then.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: He'll hurt no woman—But for the men—

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Can he make 'em better, sir? if he cou'd, we shou'd be much oblig'd to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: And he shall, lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Then let it be quickly, for I'll stay 'till they are mended, before I think of a husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: What think you, sweet lady, of the hero, him∣self?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: My thoughts must not run after such costly fruit.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: My nephew is dying for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Poor young man! but if we were both dying, my guardian would see us at our last gaspings before he'd consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Would he! then my nephew shall talk to him— Let him alone to get the consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Your nephew, sir, is below, and begs to be ad∣mitted to the idol of his affections.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Shew the gentleman up.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Idol of his affections! there's an expression for you—my nephew is a fine scholar and a great heroe— here he is—I shall leave you together—your servant, madam.

DIV3.P: To her, nephew, now is your time—I have clear'd the way—she is your own—you'll have a fine reception—I am glad to see you are half drunk—be bold and conquer.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Ne'er fear me, uncle, when I am rocky I defy any woman in Christendom—I have not been in bed to∣night—when I am bosky I never flinch.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: To her, to her, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Shall I attack her with a little learning, Dwindle; if I could but put her into confusion, the town's my own.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: Give her a broad-side then.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I had rather beat the watch, than talk to her— my courage fails me, Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: I must send this fool a packing—do you trust yourself abroad, sir, without your uncle?—you are very young, and there are a great many coaches and carts, in this metropolis!

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Coaches and carts, Dwindle! I am dumb, et vox faucibus haesit.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: Give her one fire first.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I had rather go back again, Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: What, turn your back upon the enemy!

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I can't face her, per dios immortales!

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: If you have any matter to communicate, let me beg to know it immediately, for I am in haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I had much matter to communicate, but your coaches and carts have drove it quite out of my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Poor gentleman! when you have recovered your senses, and the use of your tongue, return to me again, and I shall be at your service; in the mean time, I would recommend a gentle nap to you, and I'll pay a visit to my monkey; and so, sir, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: This is a fine reception truly, Dwindle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: So, so, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: I am in a damn'd passion, Dwindle—I'll go and kick her monkey.

SP.SPEAKER: Dwin.
SP.P: Leave that to me, sir, and I'll do his bu∣siness.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: But this must not pass so! what does my un∣cle mean, and Mr. Wilding mean, by sending me here to be laugh'd at—if I meet 'em, woe betide 'em—I am so full, that unless I have some vent, I shall burst—don't speak to me, Dwindle, or I shall certainly fall upon you— O for a man, woman, or child now!—I must beat some∣thing.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the street, Enter Hazard and Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: How now, Will, thou look'st desperately this morning, did'st sleep well to-night.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Do not enquire, but curse yourself 'till noon. I am charitable; I do not bid thee hang thyself: and yet I have cause to thank thee. I would not have lost the turn, for all the money I won last night,—such a delicious theft!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I found it so, and dare make my affidavit.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Thou didst not see her?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Nor speak to her: to what purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Now do I
Grow melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: If thou do'st envy me,
There is some reason for't; thou dost imagine
I have had pleasure in my days; but never,
Never, so sweet a skirmish! not a kiss,
But had elysium in't.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I was a rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: If thou didst know but half so much as I,
Or couldst imagine it, thou wouldst acknowledge
Thyself worse than a rascal on record.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I have not words t'express, how soft, how bounteous,
How every thing a man with full desires
Could wish a lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Prithee be quiet—but tell me, Will—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Don't question me farther;
It is too much happiness to remember;
I am sorry I have said so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Was not I curs'd
To lose my money, and such delicate sport?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: But that I love thee well, shouldst ne'er enjoy her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I would almost cut thy throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: You wou'd not.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: But take her! and if thou part'st with her one night more, for less than both the Indies, thou'lt lose by her; she has paid me for my service; I ask nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: If she be such a precious morsel, Will,
I think you may be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Take heed,
And understand thyself a little better:
I think you may be satisfied—with what?
A handsome wench! 'tis heresy; recant it;
I never shall be satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: You do not purpose
A new encounter.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: For thy sake,
'Tis possible I may not; I would have
My game kept for me. What I have done, faith,
Was upon your entreaty; if you have
The like occasion hereafter, I
Should have a hard heart to deny thee, Jack.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Thou hast fir'd my blood! that I could call back time,
To be possess'd of what my indiscretion
Gave up to thy enjoying! but I am comforted;
She thinks 'twas I; and we hereafter may
Be free in our delights—Now, sir, the news
With you?

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: My mistress did command my diligence
To find you out, and pray you come to speak with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: When I am at leisure.

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: 'Tis of consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Is Penelope with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.L: Not when she sent me forth.
Shall I tell my mistress you will come to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: How officious you are for your mistress, sirrah—
What said she, I came not home all night?

SP.SPEAKER: Page.
SP.P: Nothing to me—but my eyes ne'er beheld her look so pleasantly.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Well, well, say I'll come.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Now farewel, Jack.—I need not urge your se∣cresy touching your mistress—I must laugh at thee, and heartily, ha, ha, ha!—So farewel, farewel, Jack, ha, ha, ha!—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: To say the truth, I have shew'd myself a cox-comb. A pox o' play! that made me double loser. For aught I know, she may admit me never to such a turn again—And then I ha' punish'd myself ingeniously— O fool! fool! fool!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, Wilding's House.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Is he coming, say'st thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I saw him turn at the corner of the square.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Is he alone?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Alone, and seems disorder'd; with his eyes upon the ground, and his arms folded thus; he walks by starts, and shews all is not right within.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Now comes the trial—Hark! I hear him—You must away—Now for it.

DIV3.P:
So, my good penitent man—I find your conscience was sincere; you have at last taken a farewel to your follies,
but such dear friends you were, you took up all the night in parting.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: I have bid farewel to 'em for ever—It was the last effort of expiring passion, but 'tis gone, and now I'm a new man.—Heigho.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Why do you sigh, husband?
How d'ye, sweetheart?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Well; but a little melancholy.
You look more sprightfully, wife; something has pleas'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: It has indeed; and if it be no stain
To modesty, I would enquire how you
Sped the last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I lost my money.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I don't mean that.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Don't mean that?—I am not betray'd, I Ghope! what do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Y'are a fine gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: 'Tis so; could she not keep her own counsel?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: And have behav'd yourself most wittily,
And I may say most wrongfully: this will
Be much for your honour, when 'tis known.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: What will be known?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Do you not blush? oh fie!
Is there no modesty in man?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Riddle my riddle my re—Pox of your ambi∣guities: what would you have?—I would not yet seem conscious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: 'Tis time then to be plain; it was a wonder
I could be so long silent: did you like
Your last night's lodging?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Very, very well;
I went not to bed all night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Not to bed, all night!—think again, my dear—your mem'ry may fail you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: What do you mean?—I say I have not been in bed to-night—and had you any eyes but jealous ones, you'd see by mine I have not slept to-night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Look at me, husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: So I do—there! there!—What mummery's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Now tell me—do you feel no small com∣punction at thus looking in my injur'd face?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: A pox upon these stale expostulations; must I ever be dinn'd with 'em? and can't my reformation work a change in you?—thou art the strangest woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Soft, soft my good husband—did not you meet Penelope last night?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: No, I met no Penelope last night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: And were you not to meet her?—speak, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Prithee, let me alone, my head aches.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: No, no, 'tis my head that aches—did you not pass the night, the live-long night, in wanton, stolen embraces?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Refuse me if I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: You did not lie with Mrs. Penelope, my kinswoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Cuckold me, if I did. I swear—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Come, come, don't swear—but 'twas no fault of yours, no fault, no virtue—but this is no time to expostulate these actions—in brief, know 'twas my plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: What plot?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Yes, yes, my plot, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: My plot, my dear! what do you smirk and giggle at?—Leave your ideot tricks and tell me what you mean.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: You are so testy—but I shall please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Shall you? I wish you would—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P:
Thus then—I have with sorrow long observ'd which way your warm affection mov'd, and found 'twould be in vain with open pow'r t' oppose you; I therefore work'd by stratagem—I got the secret of your meeting, and I wrought so with my honest cousin,
to supply her wanton place, that with some shame, at last, I might deceive your hard heart into kindness.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: That, that again, sweet wife; and be a little
Serious—Was it your plot to excuse your cousin,
And be the bedfellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: 'Twas indeed, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: 'Twas in hell, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Bless me!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I am fitted, fitted with a pair of horns Of my own making!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: What, do you take it thus?
Should you not rather thank, and think upon
That providence, that would not have you lost
In such a forest of loose thoughts: come, be
Yourself again; I am your handmaid still;
And have learn'd so much piety to conceal
Whatever should dishonour you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: It buds—
It buds already! I shall turn starkmad—
Horn mad!—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: What ails you? are you vex'd
Because your wantonness has thriv'd so well?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Well with a vengeance! and did you really con∣trive the plot yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I did.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: You lie—I contriv'd some part of it—and can you prove all this to be true?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: I can—witness those tender joys, which, tho' not meant for me—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: O damn your description!
I am satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: You seem angry—I did expect your thanks.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Yes, I do thank you, thank you heartily;
Most infinitely thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Doth this merit
No other payment but your scorn? then know,
Bad man, 'tis in my power to be reveng'd;
And what I had a resolution
Should sleep in silent darkness, now shall look
Day in the face; I'll publish to the world
How I am wrong'd, and with what stubbornness
You have despis'd the cure of your own fame;
Nor shall my cousin suffer in her honour.
I stoop as low as earth to shew my duty;
But too much trampled on, I rise to tell
The world, I am a woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No, no; hark you,
I do not mock you. I am taken with
The conceit; what a fine thing I have made myself?
Ne'er speak on't, thy device shall take; I'll love thee,
And kiss thee for't; thou'st paid me handsomely:
An admirable plot, and follow'd cunningly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Then I'm happy, husband, if you're sin∣cere.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: O very sincere, and very happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: In earnest then of that sincerity,
Vouchsafe the kiss you promised—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: There—there.—
I'll see thee anon again; and lie with thee
To-night, without a stratagem. Penelope
Expects thee; keep all close; dear wife, no sentences.

DIV3.L: I'm trick'd and trimm'd at my own charges rarely!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I Am justly punish'd now for all my tricks,
And pride o'th' flesh! I had ambition
To make men cuckolds; now the devil has paid me,
Paid me i'th' same coin; and I'll compare
My forehead with the broadest of my neighbours:
But, e'er it spreads too monstrous, I must have
Some plot upon this Hazard. He supposes
He has enjoy'd Penelope, and my trick's
To drive the opinion home, to get him marry her,
And make her satisfaction. The wench
Has oft commended him: he may be won to't.
I never meant to part with all her portion:
Perhaps he'll thank me for the moiety;
And this dispos'd on, she's conjur'd to silence.
It must be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Jack Wilding, how is't, man?
How goes the plow at home? what says the lady
Guinever, that was humbled in your absence?
You have the credit with her, all the glory:
What says she, Jack? does she not hide her eyes,
And blush, and cry you are a fine gentleman!
Turn a one side, or drop a handkerchief,
And stoop, and take occasion to leer
And laugh upon thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild▪
SP.L: Nothing less: I know not
What thou'st done to her, but she's very sad.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I'll be hang'd then.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Thou must imagine,
I did the best to comfort her.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: She's melancholy
For my absence, man: I'll keep her company
Again to night.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: And nothing now but sighs, and cries I have Undone her.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Ay, ay, the old cant—she's a fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: To be plain,
Although she has no thought but I was her gallant,
You are the only argument of her sadness.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: How can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: When I had merrily
Excus'd what had been done, she fetch'd a sigh,
And with some tears reveal'd her love to you;
That she had lov'd you long, but by this act
Of mine, d'y' mark? she was become unworthy
To hope so good a fortune; I cannot tell,
But she is strangely passionate.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: For me?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Ay, for you:

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Why, now I do recollect myself,
She has sometimes smil'd upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Nay, believe it,
She is taken with thee above all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And yet she was content you should—
'Bove all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: But 'twas your better fate
To be the man; it was her destiny
Contriv'd it thus—thou art a gentleman,
And must consider the poor gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What wou'd'st ha' me do?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Make her amends.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What do you mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Marry a strumpet!

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: You had first possession, and had'st thou married earlier, thou cou'dst but have had her first; besides, none know but we ourselves, and we, for weighty reasons, must be secret.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Why, ay, that's true, but then for weightier reasons, I must not marry her—

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Come, come, thou hast a tender heart,
Heav'n knows! she may be desperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
Wild.
SP.P: I know thou art more charitable; she may prove a happy wife; what woman but has frailty?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Let her make the best on't; set up shop i' th' Strand or Westminster, she may have custom.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: She has a portion will maintain her like a gentle∣woman, and your wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Where is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: In my possession; and I had rather thou Shouldst have it than another.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Thank you heartily.
A single life has single care; pray keep it.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Come, thou shalt know I love thee—thou shalt have
More by a thousand pound, than I resolv'd
To part with, 'cause I wou'd call thee cousin too:
Five thousand pound, Will, she has to her portion!
I hop'd to put her off with half the sum,
That's truth;—some younger brother would have thank'd me,
And given me my quietus—is't a match?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: A pretty sum! five thousand pound will make What's crooked, straight again.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Th'art in the right;
Or for the better sound, as the grammarians
Say, I will call it—fifty hundred pound!
B'r lady, a pretty stock; enough, an' need be,
To buy up half the women in a county.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Here's my hand; I'll consider on't no farther;
Is she prepar'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Leave that to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: No more.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I'll instantly about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Will you confirm this before witnesses?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Bring a hundred—bring 'em presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I'll follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Now I'm a little easy—
The bitt'rest pill when gilded, will be swallow'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Ha, ha!
The project moves better than I expected;
What pains he takes out of his ignorance?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Oh! sir, I am glad I ha' found you.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I was not lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: My nephew, sir, my nephew!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: He's undone, he's undone! you have undone him.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You have made him, sir, so valiant, I am afraid
He's not long liv'd; he quarrels now with every body:
And roars and domineers, and shakes the pent-houses.
What shall I do? I fear he will be kill'd:
I take a little privilege myself,
Because I threaten to disinherit him;
But no body else dares talk, or meddle with him;
Is there no way to take him down again,
And make him coward?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: There are ways to tame him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Now I wish heartily you had beaten him
For the hundred pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: That may be done yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Is't not too late? but d'ye think 'twill humble him?
I expect every minute he's abroad
To hear he has kill'd somebody, or receive him
Brought home with half his brains, or but one leg.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: What wou'd you have me do?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I'll pay you for't,
If you will beat him soundly, sir, and leave him
But as you found him: for if he continue
A blade, and be not kill'd, he won't escape
The gallows long; and 'tis not for my honour
He should be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I shall deserve as much
To allay this metal, as I did to quicken it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Nay, 'tis my meaning to content you, sir;
And I shall take it as a favour too,
If for the same price you made him valiant,
You will unblade him: here's the money, sir;
As weighty gold as t'other; 'cause you should not
Lay it on lightly: break no limb, and bruise him
Three quarters dead, I care not: he may live
Many a fair day after it.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: You shew
An uncle's love in this; trust me to cure
His valour.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: He's here; do but observe,

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: How now, uncle?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Thou art no nephew of mine, th'art a rascal!
I'll be at no more charge to make thee a gentleman:
Pay for your dice and drinkings; I shall have
The surgeons bills brought shortly home to me;
Be troubled to bail thee from the sessions;
And afterwards make friends to the recorder
For a reprieve, yes—I will see thee hang'd first.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: And be at the charge to paint the gallows too;
If I have a mind, the waits shall play before me;
And I'll be hang'd in state, three stories high, uncle:
But first I'll cut your throat.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Bless me! defend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: How now, what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: Master Barnacle!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: There's an ungracious bird of mine own nest,
Will murder me.

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: He wo'not sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Put up,
And ask your uncle presently forgiveness;
Or I will huff thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Huff me?—I will put up
At thy intreaty.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Gentlemen, you remember
This noble gallant.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Cousin of yours, I take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Cousin to a killing, in your company
Lent me a box o'th' ear.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: No, no, I gave it,
I gave it freely; keep it, never think on't;
I can make bold with thee another time;
Wou'd it had been twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: One's too much to keep.
I am a gamester, and remember always
My debts of honor—First, the principal—

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Use? wou'd th'adst given it my uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: They have cost him already two hundred pounds
And upwards, shotten herring, thing of noise!

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Oh, for my man Dwindle,
And his basket-hilt now! my uncle shall rue this.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Down presently, and, before these gentlemen,
Desire his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: How! desire his pardon?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Do it I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: I will ask his pardon; I beseech you, uncle—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And swear.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: And do swear.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: To be obedient, never more to quarrel.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Why, look you, gentlemen, I hope you are per∣swaded,
By taking this so patiently, that I am
Not over valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I suspect him still.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Indeed you need not, uncle.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: If ever he prove rebellious, in act
Or language, let me know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Will you not give
Me leave to roar abroad, a little, for my credit?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Never, sirrah; now I'll tame you.
I thank you, gentlemen; command me for
This courtesy.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: 'Tis possible I may
With less noise grow more valiant hereafter:
'Till then I am in all your debts.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Be rul'd,
And be my nephew again: this was my love,
My love, dear nephew.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: If your love consist
In kicking, uncle, let me love you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Be silent, sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: I am dumb.

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Then his uncle paid for't?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Heartily, heartily.
Whither are you going, gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: As you shall lead us, Hazard.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: 'Tis lucky then;
Will you be witnesses to a desperate
Bargain I mean to drive within this hour?—
No less than bartering for my liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sell.
SP.L: The devil! not to be married, sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: 'Tis even so—and were I sure that this, my valiant friend, (to Neph.) would not be angry at my choice, I'd tell you who was the maid elect.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Chuse where you list; I'll ne'er be angry more, nor woo again; I have had of both my quantum sufficit.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Her name's Penelope.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.P: Take her, and welcome; she'll pay you in the coin you've favor'd me with.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: May you win and wear her, Mr. Hazard; and since my nephew merits not the maid, I wish you and her happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Thanks, Mr. Barnacle—I will away to Wild∣ing's, and prepare for your reception—will you fol∣low me?

SP.SPEAKER: Litt.
SP.L: We will.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: What say you, gentlemen? shall we drink this couple in a glass of sack, and then to wish 'em joy?

SP.SPEAKER: Acr.
SP.L: Agreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: I'm for any thing.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, Wilding's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Why, you would not have me encourage this Hazard?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Indeed but I wou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: What, a gamester! a profligate!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: His gaming is accidental—A younger brother, and bred to no business, naturally leads to the dice for his supplies—I know he is tir'd of the com∣pany he has kept; his honour is as yet unimpeach'd, and with your fortune, what can either of you want, or desire farther?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.P: Indeed, I dare not think of it. Give me a little time—and—who knows—Lord, he's here.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.P: Mr. Hazard, I have pleaded hard for you, and promised much for you—You must now try the cause yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I am indebted to you—all things succeed be∣yond your thought—pray, give me a little opportu∣nity with your kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: I'll withdraw.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: I know not how to woo her— Sweet lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Your pleasure, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Pray, let me ask you a question—
If you had lost your way, and met one,
A traveller like myself, that knew the coast
O'th'country, would you thank him to direct you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: That common manners would instruct.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I think so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: But there are many ways to the wood.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And which
Would you desire; the nearest path, and safest,
Or that which leads about?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Without all question,
The nearest and safest.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Can you love then?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I were a devil else.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: And can you love a man?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: A man! what else, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Y'are so far on your way. Now love but me,
Y'are at your journey's end; what say you to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Nothing, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: That's no answer, you must say something.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I hope you'll not compel me.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: D'y' hear, lady?
Setting this foolery aside, I know
You cannot chuse but love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I have been told so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: You are easy of belief;
I think I should be best acquainted with
My own thoughts, and I dare not be so desperate
To conclude.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Come, come; y'are a dissembling gentlewoman.
I know your heart; you have lov'd me a great while.
What should I play the fool for? if you remember,
I urg'd some wild discourse in the behalf
Of Barnacle; it was a trial of thee;
That humour made me love thee; and since that, thy virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Indeed, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Indeed, sir? why I have been contracted to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: How long?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: This half hour; know thy portion, and shall have it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Strange!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Nay, I'll have thee too.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: You will?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I cannot help it; thy kind cousin will have it so:
'Tis his own plot, to make thee amends; is't not
Good mirth? but 'tis not love to thee or me;
But to have me possest he is no cuckold:
I see through his device, thou art much beholden to him:
He meant to have put thee off with half thy portion;
But that, as things have hap'd, we must keep secret.
Say, is't a match? I have two thousand pound too,
I thank the dice: let's put our stocks together;
Children will follow—He is here already.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: So close! I am glad on't, this prepares Will Hazard,
And my young cousin—A word, Penelope.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Now will he make all sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: You us'd me coarsely,
But I have forgot it; what discourse have you
With this gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: He would seem to be a suitor.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Entertain him, d'y' hear; you may do worse be rul'd.
'Twas in my thought to move it; does he not
Talk strangely?

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Of nothing; let me counsel you
To love him; call him husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: I resolve
Never to marry without your consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Gentlemen, welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Pen.
SP.L: If you bestow me, sir, I will be confident
I am not lost, I must confess I love him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: No more then; lose no time.—Kind gentlemen,
Y'are come most seasonably to be the witnesses
Of my consent; I have examin'd both
Your hearts, and freely give thee here my kinswoman:
No sooner shall the church pronounce
You married, but challenge what is her's.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Five thousand pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I do confess it is her portion;
You sh'not stay to talk—Nay, gentlemen,
Pray see the business finish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Acre.
SP.L: We'll attend him.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The lawyer with his papers are within;
I've sign'd and seal'd the contract, and with it
Give up all my right and guardianship
To this my friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Which I with joy accept of—

DIV3.L: Be you the witnesses. Come on.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: So, so; this will confirm him in the opinion,
Penelope was the creature he enjoy'd,
And keep off all suspicion of my wife;
Who is still honest, in the imagination
That only I embrac'd her: all's secure,
And my brow's smooth again. Who can deride me,
But I myself? Ha! that's too much; I know it;
And spite of these tricks, am a Cornelius.
Cannot I bribe my conscience to be ignorant?
Why then I ha' done nothing: yes, advanc'd
The man, that grafted shame upon my fore-head:
Vexation! parted with five thousand pound,
And am no less a cuckold than before:
Was I predestin'd to this shame aud mockery?
Where were my brains? yet why am I impatient?
Unless betray'd, he cannot reach the knowledge;
And then no matter—yes, I am curst again;
My torment multiplies; Penelope
Will clear herself, and then that ruins all!
I wou'd she had been strumpeted. I am lost,
And must be desperate—kill him? no—my wife.
Not so good—death is over black and horrid;
And I am grown ridiculous to myself.—
I must do something.—

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: Master Wilding, welcome—I have not seen you a great while.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Then I have been happy a great while.
Do you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Know you?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: They say I am much alter'd of late.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: There is some alteration in your forehead.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: My forehead!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.P: 'Tis not smooth enough—you're troubled—Is your wife within?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: What wou'd you with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I know the matter that's a brewing.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: Et ego.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: You have it here, Mr. Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: The devil!—Do you see 'em?
Have they broke the surface?

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: I mean Mr. Hazard's business.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I mean that too—My head's a torment to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Neph.
SP.L: What wou'd you give now, Mr. Wilding, to be of the nation without heads?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Wou'd I cou'd change conditions with these fools; they are not troubled now with being cuckolds.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: Gentlemen, your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Joy, joy to you, Mrs. Wilding.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: Wife, you are a whore; you shall know more hereafter—I must go live in the forest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: And I i'th' common.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: She'll turn prostitute!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Your leave, gentle folks; who wishes us joy!

SP.SPEAKER: Bar.
SP.L: Married?

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Fast as the law can tie us;
The priest must bless the knot.

SP.SPEAKER: Acre.
SP.L: We are witnesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.P: Cousin, five thousand pound; and lady, now I must thank you for this among the rest—Look then with an eye of love upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.P: No matter, she'll love thee afterwards. An' she do not, she can but cuckold thee; there be more i'th' pa∣rish, man.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: In our parish, husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: I'll be divorc'd now,
Wife, you're a whore—

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: Ho there! no big words; come,
We must tell something in your ear: be merry;
You are no cuckold, make no noise.—I know
That's it offends your stomach.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Haz.
SP.L: I touch'd not her, nor this, with one rude action.
We'll talk the circumstance another time:
Yo wife expected you; but when I came,
She had prepar'd a light, and her cousin here,
T' have made you blush, and chide you into honesty:
Seeing their chaste simplicity, I was won
To silence, which brought on my better fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Wild.
SP.L: Can this be real?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Wild.
SP.L: By my hopes of peace
I'th' t'other world, you have no injury▪
My plot was only to betray you to
Love and repentance.
